brief_description of the content in the: The source URL describes a rule that checks for mismatches between @PathVariable parameters declared in the method signature and those present in the URL path. If a mismatch is found, a quick-fix is suggested to add the missing parameter.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'pathVariableMismatch' checks all classes and their methods. If a method has the '@PathVariable' annotation, it retrieves the name of the path variable and the URL path from the '@RequestMapping' annotation. It then asserts that the URL path contains the path variable name. If it does not, a message is generated indicating the mismatch, including the method name, class fully qualified name, path variable name, and URL path.
PRE_model_validation: The rule 'pathVariableMismatch' is syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses only the built-in functions provided, such as 'getClasses', 'getMethods', 'hasAnnotation', 'getAnnoAttr', 'contains', and 'msg'. The rule does not introduce any new built-in functions.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. https://www.baeldung.com/spring-pathvariable-constraints: This page from Baeldung discusses the use of @PathVariable in Spring MVC and how to apply constraints to them. It does not directly address the mismatch issue but provides a good understanding of how @PathVariable is used.
2. https://stackoverflow.com/questions/3686808/spring-3-requestmapping-get-path-value: This StackOverflow thread discusses how to get the path value from a @RequestMapping annotation in Spring MVC. It indirectly relates to the rule as it deals with the extraction of URL path, which is a part of the rule.
